newsitem.title: HUNGARY: MOTOR RACING-HILL SPRINGS SURPRISE IN BUDAPEST.
newsitem.headline: MOTOR RACING-HILL SPRINGS SURPRISE IN BUDAPEST.

text.p: Reigning world champion Damon Hill stunned everyone including himself on Saturday when he claimed third place on the starting grid for Sunday's Hungarian Grand Prix.
Since leaving Williams at the end of last year, the Briton has struggled to impose himself with his new Arrows team, collecting only one championship point this season.
But he turned back the clock to post his best lap in the dying seconds of the session and finished just ahead of Finn Mika Hakkinen in a McLaren.

Championship leader Michael Schumacher secured his 17th pole position, with a best time of one minute 14.672 seconds in his Ferrari and Jacques Villeneuve, in his Williams, was 0.187 of a second slower to claim the other place on the front row.
"I could not believe it myself at first. I saw the readout in my cockpit and did not think it was right. I thought something had gone wrong," Hill admitted.
"It is absolutely fantastic to be back up here and so competitive.
"I really thought a place in the top 10 would have been brilliant. Now I will go out to really enjoy myself in the race. Can I win? Of course, I can. Anything can happen."

Hill won his first Formula One victory at the Hungaroring in 1993 and triumphed again in 1995. He finished second last year and there is no doubt that his know-how was an important factor in negotiating a difficult circuit.

His team boss Tom Walkinshaw described Hill's effort as "world class" and it is now possible, according to some sources close to Hill, that he may consider Arrows sufficiently competitive to remain with them in 1998.
"It is too early to talk about that. All I want to do is to concentrate on this race this weekend and make the most of it," he said.
Hill, criticised for not doing his best on the eve of the British Grand Prix at Silverstone four weeks ago, received a standing ovation from the team when he returned to the pits.
"I knew it was possible because it is so tight and competitive but I did not expect it to come off quite like this," he said.
Hill now has a chance of being an unexpected player in the championship battle between Schumacher and Villeneuve.
"I know they will have a lot more pressure on them than I will have on me," said Hill. "I've been there and it is a factor. I can be relaxed and just have some fun."
